author: carlton
content:
Dear Anju,
I have checked both questions, and I am getting the answer that is within the provided range.
GA3 is challenging. If I may be completely candid, it looks like an answer spat out by GPT. For example there is a meaningless operation
match = pattern.match (line)
Why? what’s wrong with just line? (assuming logs are an array of lines)
Did you try to examine the output of a few samples of each match to see if you are actually getting the expected output at each stage of the regex?
It might be that your regex is not performing as expected and filtering out the wrong lines. Regex is a tough and unforgiving tool to debug.
I will show how to solve this in the live TA session, and I will show a much simpler method that is humanly easily verifiable.
From the movie Maverick Topgun…
The end is inevitable, Maverick. Your kind is headed for extinction.
jjaevdoscwpb12034×1203 322 KB
Someday GPT will relegate such skills obsolete… But until that day…
Yours truly,
TDS TA
PS: Moral of the story is its okay to use GPT. In fact we encourage it (it is the future), but please try to do some basic debugging and checks first. Use GPT in a progressive step wise fashion so that you can verifiably solve the problem. I am here to guide you on your TDS journey. I will not be able to debug GPT’s code all the time because, lets face it. GPT knows a lot more than me. It just does not have “brains”. So sometimes you need to think about what is actually happening instead of completely treating it as a magic black box. Cheers!

author: HimanshuSaini
carlton
content:
Typically, the on page console tools will be more accurate as it is able to retrieve correctly the complete dom straight from the browser.
Beautiful soup although very good, can sometimes run into some limitations because certain scripts are not triggerred correctly when retrived by an agent other than a browser.
Thats why its good to learn both methods.

topic_title: Scraping the IMDb browser using Javascript
author: vikram_negi
content:
Try this:
$$('.ipc-metadata-list-summary-item').map(item => [
    item.querySelector('.ipc-title__text').textContent,
    item.querySelector('.sc-8f57e62c-1:nth-child(1)').querySelector('span:last-child').textContent,
    item.querySelector('.sc-8f57e62c-1:nth-child(2)').querySelector('span:last-child').textContent,
    item.querySelector('.sc-8f57e62c-1:nth-child(3)').querySelector('span:last-child').textContent,
    item.querySelector('.ipc-rating-star--rating').textContent,
    item.querySelector('.ipc-rating-star--voteCount').textContent.trim(),
]);

Note: The CSS pseudo-class selector, selects the n-th child of a parent element. In this example, I sc-8f57e62c-1 is the class of the li element.

The first clue comes from the HTTP response code. 403

MDN Web Docs



HTTP response status codes - HTTP | MDN
HTTP response status codes indicate whether a specific HTTP request has been successfully completed.
  Responses are grouped in five classes:





Try and change the user_agent to something that is personalised to your application and give it a try.
Kind regards

topic_title: BONUS MARK: LLM app development + video
author: s.anand
content:
Here is an OPTIONAL project: Record a 10-minute video in which you create an application entirely using LLMs and deploy it.

Any app is fine. Any language. Simple or complex. Business or gaming. Anything is fine. Your choice.
Create the app only using LLMs. You can use an LLM (ChatGPT, Claude.ai, Gemini, Cursor, Cody, etc.) but you can only prompt the app to write code. You can copy-paste code and run code don’t write or edit even a single line of code directly. Use LLMs to debug and edit. Code completion is NOT allowed – only prompting/chatting.
Record the entire process in 10 min. Don’t edit, trim, enhance, or annotate the video. You should record yourself creating the entire app from start to finish. Practice beforehand if you like. Record in 1 take.
Share the video and app. Publish the video publicly anywhere (e.g. YouTube and share the link.) Publish the app publicly anywhere (e.g. GitHub pages, Glitch.me, Heroku, etc.) or upload a ZIP file with the code (for slightly lower marks.)

Submit via a reply to this thread. Multiple submissions per person are fine. Work in groups if you like but only the submitter gets marks.
I will award up to 1 bonus mark at my discretion based on:

How well you prompt the LLM
How impressive the app is (if you’ve hosted it - I probably won’t run your code)
How closely you followed the rules above

This exercise is to help you (and me) learn a topic that’ll probably change the way we all code: using LLMs to code.
Cutoff date: 7 Oct 2024, AoE

author: carlton
content:
Typically disk usage which is in blocks rather than bytes is different from how many bytes a file is. A 3 byte file might still take 4KB on disk if the smallest disk block size is 4KB (default on NT)
You are getting the disk usage space which varies from computer to computer rather than answering the exact question that was asked.
Kind regards

author: carlton
content:
A simpler solution is to simply use the ls -l command and send the output to a file, which  can then be easily processed.
Of course you could use a bash script as well. But if you are not proficient in bash, it would very hard to diagnose what is wrong.
Why wield a samurai sword which requires great skill and experience to slice bread, when you can just do it with your kitchen bread knife instead?
Kind regards

author: s.anand
content:
Fascinating! https://anshulbaliga7.github.io/tds-iitm/index.html is UTF-16 encoded text that’s being served as UTF-8. Browsers handle the conversion automatically, but code does not.
@anshul_baliga7 – please re-encode as UTF-8 or plain ASCII. And welcome to the complications of character encoding. For more details, there’s a great video by Scott Hanselman is a great introduction.

author: anshul_baliga7
content: Worked! Thank you sir!

author: AnkitS
content:
Sir, could you please tell what clue led you to catch this discrepancy?
Because if we look, it all looks same to us on the browser whether its UTF-16 or UTF-8.

author: s.anand
content:
It looked the same to me, too. So I cloned the repo (I think – I might have run curl on the URL) and piped it through od -ha which gives an octal dump. That’s where I spotted a bunch of weird characters.
You could also clone it and open it in an editor like VS Code. You’ll see the encoding at the bottom-right.

author: s.anand
content:
@22f3001318 – yes, that can happen.
This is a good opportunity to talk about two-way doors. Jeff Bezos wrote:

Some decisions are consequential and irreversible or nearly irreversible – one-way doors – and these decisions must be made methodically, carefully, slowly, with great deliberation and consultation. If you walk through and don’t like what you see on the other side, you can’t get back to where you were before. We can call these Type 1 decisions. But most decisions aren’t like that – they are changeable, reversible – they’re two-way doors. If you’ve made a suboptimal Type 2 decision, you don’t have to live with the consequences for that long. You can reopen the door and go back through. Type 2 decisions can and should be made quickly by high judgment individuals or small groups
As organizations get larger, there seems to be a tendency to use the heavy-weight Type 1 decision-making process on most decisions, including many Type 2 decisions. The end result of this is slowness, unthoughtful risk aversion, failure to experiment sufficiently, and consequently diminished invention. We’ll have to figure out how to fight that tendency

GA1 is a good example of a 2-way door. Try an approach. If the answer is incorrect, try another. You get instant feedback. No need to check.
Here’s what I suggest. Go ahead and let the newer file replace the older one. If the answer’s incorrect, try it the other way around. One or the other will work if you have the rest of the steps right.
But to your question, yes, duplicate files CAN occur.

author: 21f1002976
content:
I faced the same scenario where I had two files with same name, but case sensitive as ‘u.txt’ and ‘U.txt’ in the same folder. In windows and WSL I was forced to keep either one.
Then I had to upload the file to my google drive, mounted it on Colab and used the tried it on Colab Terminal. The terminal on Colab was using a different file system and it was accepting same names with case sensitivity.
image738×690 25.3 KB
you can see ‘u.txt’ and ‘U.txt’
The same steps and commands on WSL was giving me wrong SHA key. But when I used the same steps on Colab Terminal, it worked.

author: carlton
content:
Windows files system is case insensitive. Linux typically uses a case sensitive filesystem (although you can configure it to whatever you wanted).
Typically a VM is completely isolated, however because WSL still has to be accessible to the windows filesystem (you can for example view the WSL filesystem directly from windows file explorer), it seems to have been configured with a case insensitive filesystem. This is odd in your case because Windows documentation seems to suggest the default is otherwise. Case Sensitivity | Microsoft Learn
Google Colab notebooks has a linux backend and currently runs on Ubuntu 22.04
You can run these in your google colab to see what it runs

!cat /etc/*release

This is the file system info

!df -Th

Incredibly on ext4 (which typically what most default linux systems use), you are even able to enable case insensitivity on a directory by directory basis! (for those power users that have very specific use cases). Windows also claims to now support this feature on NT through the use of directory flags.
Nice bit of work.
Kind regards

I am sure there will be others in a similar situation too.
Things being what they are (I didn’t know about these prerequisites early enough, so I didn’t prepare during the three-week gap after the last term exams), can you please suggest some references—documents, books, articles, sites, or YouTube playlists—for getting started in the best possible way? It would have been nice if such content were curated and added as Week 0—MLF has a Week 0 where they list out some topics from statistics and mathematics.

All that we need

TL;DR
Please provide some structured resources for the prerequisites, such as articles, documents, books, or YouTube playlists.
Thanks for any help and your time.

topic_title: Prerequisites for TDS - request for resources
author: carlton
content:
Hi Hari,
Please refer to the course introduction page. Most students ignore this page, but for TDS it is a source of very valuable information.

You should be comfortable coding in Python, HTML, JavaScript, Excel, and have a basic understanding of data science concepts.

GA0 is meant to point you to the problem (skill requirements). We will provide some more specific resources as the course progresses, but for the above, any google search will provide you good beginner resources to get started. One of the key skills of Data Science is given a problem, finding the data.
How you solve that problem is part of your growth. Since these are very basic requirements, we do not typically give recommendations as everyone has a different learning style. You have to find resources that suit your style.
For the more in depth topics we will cover them in the live sessions, lectures and the resource links we will provide that go with those topics.
Please feel free to contribute what you have discovered to be great resources (as new ones keep popping up and they are quite good, so it will be good for all of us including the TDS team, to see what students find). Last term for example @eram1011 did a phenomenal job of collating information of the various resources for TDS.




TDS May 2024 Portal Resource Links Tools in Data Science


    Here is the collection of all the links provided on the portal up to the current week for the May 2024 term for learning TDS. I felt the need to save all of them for my learning checklist and future reference. I’m sharing this in the hope that it might save you some time if you also need the links in one place. I plan to update this post regularly with week-wise content. 

WEEK1 Data discovery 


https://datasetsearch.research.google.com/
https://data.gov/
https://data.gov.ru/?language=en 

…
  

Please note that each term TDS changes. So not everything from last term will be the same. So not everything on that discourse post will be used. It is a good starting point.
Kind regards

topic_title: Important Course Advisory - GA0 Performance Review
author: carlton
content:
Dear Student,
This post is with regards to your performance in Graded Assignment 0 (GA0), if you scored below 60% or did not attempt the GA0 itself. This assignment was designed to assess your comfort in:

Python programming
HTML and JavaScript
Excel proficiency
Basic data science concepts

Your current score indicates significant gaps in these prerequisite skills, which are crucial for success in this course. Based on previous experience, students who start with similar skill levels typically:

Struggle to keep up with course material
Achieve lower overall grades
May face delays in their graduation timeline due to poor performance in various assessments

Recommended Action:
I strongly advise you to:

Pause and reassess your readiness for this course
Strengthen your foundational skills in the areas mentioned above
Consider taking this course in a future semester when better prepared

If you choose to continue despite this warning, please understand:

The course pace and difficulty will not be adjusted
Grade accommodations will not be made
Your final grade will reflect your actual performance

Your academic success is important to us, which is why we’re providing this candid feedback. Please make an informed decision about your course enrollment.
If you need guidance on resources to improve your skills, feel free to reach out.
Best regards,
TDS Course Team

author: carlton
content:
Here is a summary of Week 1 TA session, in order to save you time from watching 2 hours of ASMR. For those that want fat free info:
TDS is practical.
READ the Course Introduction LOTs of invaluable Information.
Start preparing for ROE NOW.
End term is theory based and is much easier than GAs, Projects, ROE.
Project Score  = 80% based on answers to project questions  + 20% are from Peer Reviews.
Project comprises of Quantitative and Qualitative. Peer reviews are on the qualitative part. Reviews that are outliers are rejected.
Bonus Marks are only on Discourse. Answers must be submitted according to the Discourse post. Discretion of Bonus Marks are upto how impressed the Prof is with your submission.
Bonus Marks are really worth it. In total they are worth half of the total GAs.
Also Bonus Marks are great fun!
ROE Mocks are just previous ROEs.
There is no pattern for ROEs. They are never the same as previous ROEs.
However core skills of ROEs remain the same:

Scraping webpages. HTML, CSS, Javascript (particularly for selecting dom elements), sessions, cookies.
Scrapping PDFs. Python Tabula library.
Python (especially Pandas)
Nominatim
SQL
and maybe some other minor tools.

ROE week content: Week 2 to 4
ROE is open book (not proctored, use anything you wish including GPT)
ROE is very, very hard. Start preparing now.
SCT is NOT required for ROE.
Week 5: you will get some $ allowance for LLM tokens. Awesome. And super fun topic.
Optional Videos in week 2 are NOT optional. They are a necessary for ROE (and end term).
Bonus 1: Making LLM app: Just sharing the code on Github is not an app. Github and Github Pages are NOT the same thing. Github Pages is a web server where you can deploy your app. Github repo is just a place to store and share your code. An app is a working application that anyone with web access can use just by clicking on the link you provide.
Your app has to be submitted in the Discourse post where the Bonus post was made.
Subscribe to Discourse emails for TDS. That way you will not miss important information like the Bonus questions.
Listen to Podcast - very informational about current data science industry.
BASH - there is a great book for this from System Commands.


accounts.google.com


Google Drive: Sign-in
Access Google Drive with a Google account (for personal use) or Google Workspace account (for business use).





The links at the bottom and top of videos in the modules are very valuable.
Week 1 Video session is available on the TDS You Tube Video Playlist.


Access will NOT be given to the video links in the calendar. The ONLY place to get access to the videos will be the TDS You Tube Video Channel.
Kind regards,
TDS TA

author: lifelonglearner
content: The answers vanish and the test refreshes when you close and come back to the test. The act of closing and coming back later is equivalent to a refresh is my understanding but someone can correct if I am wrong.

author: carlton
content:
@introvert @lifelonglearner
One of the expectations of GA1 is that students complete it in one sitting. Therefore even if you submit, and come back to it, it will get refreshed.
If you have programmatically solved the question (as is the intent most of the time, because its faster, scalable, repeatable), then resolving a new set should be trivial. If you do a lot of manual solving, then yes it will be very tedious and you have not gained the learning that is expected.
Bottom line: Do the GA1 in one go.
This feature is being tested only for the GA1 (and GA0). The remaining GAs will be normal like you are used to in the seek portal.
For next term the goal is to roll this out for most if not all the GAs (in TDS at least) by learning what to improve and what achieves the best learning outcome.
Regards

author: s.anand
content:
Short answer: Please run grep . * | LC_ALL=C sort | sha256sum and it’ll work.
Long answer:
Ah, but is the second list really sorted? Should dHD BEFORE GCtPC0? Is small d before capital G?
It depends on how the UNIX sort command operates. If the locale (e.g. via the environment variable LC_ALL) is set to C, it sorts like programmers expect — uppercase before lowercase.
If it’s set to something else, e.g. en_GB.UTF, it would sort like the British do.
I missed anticipating that others’ systems would have different locale settings. Now, I’ve changed the question now to explicitly set LC_ALL=C to get consistent sorting.
Thanks for flagging this!

author: VikashKJ
content:
When extracting files from a ZIP archive using Windows’ built-in “Extract All” feature, you may notice that all extracted files have the same modification date. This is default behavior in Windows and can cause issues if you need accurate file dates.
To preserve the original file modification dates:

Use the unzip command instead of Windows’ extraction tool.
In Visual Studio Code, open a terminal as Git Bash, which provides access to the unzip command.
Run the unzip command to extract the files which will maintain their original timestamps.

Also  i had to add 1 day to get the correct answer.

author: 22f1001595
s.anand
content:
Ah, an excellent opportunity to elaborate on…
How to ask for help with TDS on Discourse

Don’t ask for the solution, e.g. “How do I solve GA3 Q4?”
Explain what you did, step by step. (Rather than “I’m not getting the answer”)
Share your ENTIRE code and ENTIRE error message. (Rather than just the part you think is relevant. The problem may be elsewhere.)
Share as copy-paste-able text. Screenshots are fine, not enough. Others have to type out your code to run or search.

If possible:

Ask ChatGPT to rewrite to craft a better question
Check for similar questions before posting
Be patient and kind. It improves your health

Do I need to rethink taking up this course? Do I first need to learn javascript and html from elsewhere and then take this course? Please clarify.
Thank you.

author: s.anand
content:
@23ds2000155 – yes, you may want to rethink.
With a strong HTML/JS foundation, you’ll score more.
Else, you’ll need to work harder, but you’ll learn more.
What would you prefer?

author: carlton
content:
Hi Viraj,
The reason for GA0 is simple. It gives you a flavour of what you need to be comfortable with in order to be able to do well in the course. Generally if you are struggling with these basics (because that is what they are), then you will have to put extra effort in order to get up to speed. TDS covers a lot of ground in terms of the tools used for Data Science. Past experience shows us that students who are not comfortable with the basics find the Remote Online Exam very challenging and many score 0.
So the GA0 gives you a chance to assess if you want to “bite the bullet” and take the course or do you want to give yourself some time to become familiar with the basic requirements. We do this early so that you can still avail the drop window, if you find the the course challenging.
We (the TDS team) have lobbied hard to actually have some concrete (programming) pre-requisites for this course, but the BS management (not the TDS team) has countered with, this is not possible because some students only do the Data Science Diploma. I totally agree that these requirements must be made known prior to taking this course. However due to an impasse on how to structure the diploma, to better deal with this issue, it is what it is. I know this is not of much comfort. Having said that, you also have one of the best professors and I dare say with the backing of data (some of the best TAs) in the program who are here to help you succeed. But it will require much effort compared to most other subjects.
Students who have been through TDS can mostly vouch for one thing. Its one of the most interesting, practical and useful course in making you job ready. But it is a trial by fire. However if you have done the diploma in programming, its fairly easy (which is why we always recommend taking it towards the end of the diploma).
Hope that helps.
Kind regards

topic_title: Discourse thread to collate Project 1 related issues
author: jkmadathil
content:
In light of the issues raised by students in Discourse regarding Project 1, the following remedial measures are being taken:
Regarding Issue of “Submit Button” for the Quantitative Submission

We have been made aware that several students submitted test runs for their project submissions and then were notified that their project has not been received. We are able to see any test runs that were submitted. We want to reassure you, if you did your "Test Run", then your last "Test Run" submission will still be considered.
If you encountered the above problem or any other portal problems, please send some evidence of the problem you encountered in this discourse thread. This will help the operations team to diagnose why this error occurred. Screenshots, error messages, etc would be helpful. Please keep everything in a single post per student (i.e do not make multiple post submissions)

Please use the poll below to indicate your issue and provide a detailed response as a reply to this post.



I was unable to click on “Submit” button, but I was able to click on “Test Run”
I was neither able to click on “Submit” nor “Test Run”
I had a different issue





0
voters




Regarding submission issues related to Peer Reviews for Project 1
Clarification
 
Peer Review submission = You submit for review from others + You review submission given by others 

And there is a causal link between these two, i.e., you submit for getting review from others and hence you receive and hence you get an opportunity to review others. It should not be treated as mutually independent events
The opportunity being provided now is for those who faced technical issues in either of the parts and due to which they were unable to submit.

On Friday, August 9, 2024 6:30 AM, we will open the peer review submissions for Project 1 and this will be open till Saturday, August 10, 2024 6:30 AM. The reviews will have to be subsequently completed by Sunday, August 11, 2024 6:30 AM. This will be your last window to submit your part 2 submission and its peer reviews. If you encounter any problems on the day, please get straight away in touch with us through this discourse thread, so that the operations team can in real time evaluate the problem that you are encountering and get you a resolution.
If you are unable to access the review submissions due to insufficient access privileges, give a zero for that review and move on to the next review.
Likewise please ensure that your project folder has been given full access permissions to “Anyone with the link”. Otherwise you will get a 0 from other reviewers.
If you have concerns about getting bad reviews, please read the Course introduction page, a clear detailed explanation is given with regards to how we handle anomalous reviews. So do not worry about it. Please do not fill up discourse with complaints about peer reviews. We have a mechanism to deal with it fairly. If on the other hand you have received 100% when you should not have… be ready to be evaluated fairly too. It cuts both ways.
Also, please note that we will be considering the marks for only those who had submission issues for the part 2 assignments earlier. In case you have already received your reviews, we will not be considering your review score for this assignment. In case you missed out on reviewing others in the earlier submission, reviewing as part of current submission will not fetch you marks.

Edit: Updated the nature of submission to include both Part 2 submission and its peer review and detailed out the cases that will be considered for final mark calculation.

topic_title: [Un Official Announcement]: May 2024 TDS Anonymous Feedback Form
author: carlton
content:
Deadline: Sunday, 15th September, 2024
Form Link:


docs.google.com



TDS May 2024 Anonymous Feedback
Deadline: Sunday, 15th September, 2024

Dear Students,

Amit and myself, were your TDS TAs for May-24 term. And we know that everything did not go smoothly as we hoped. In a few days, we will have a meeting with the course instructors and the...





Dear Students,
Amit and myself, were your TDS TAs for May-24 term. We know that everything did not go smoothly as we hoped. In a few days, we will have a meeting with the course instructors and the professor so we need your feedback to show them the right picture about this course.
This feedback form is completely anonymous. We are NOT asking for your email, roll no. or name. Your email-id is NOT recorded. You can also open this form using the incognito tab if you want. So please give us your honest opinion.
Changes for this term was the result of honest feedback:

Anand sir changed most GAs to make them more practical and allow you to apply and practise what you learnt.
Anand sir held weekly catch-up meetings with the TAs to keep up to date with the latest issues, which in turn allowed us (TAs) to respond in a timely manner to queries and problems that were raised by students through the week.
Anand sir was visibly involved with discourse, and had significant input in the creation of the Projects. He also gave students great bonus questions and gave valuable direct feedback to students.
Anand sir introduced new and relevant course content (LLMs) and removed outdated materials. This is still an ongoing process which reflects AIs growing importance to all spheres of life.

There are 3 sections to fill:

Content Feedback
Operational Feedback
Final Thoughts

Thank you for taking the time to help make TDS the best subject in the Diploma.
Your TDS TAs,
Amit and Carlton

topic_title: End term Tools in Data Science - Queries
author: carlton
content:
Network analysis is used in climate modeling to study complex interactions and relationships within the climate system. It allows researchers to understand how different components of the climate system (e.g., temperature, precipitation, atmospheric circulation) are interconnected. Here are some ways network analysis is applied in climate modeling:
Spatio-temporal network analysis for studying climate patterns | Climate Dynamics (2014)
ENSO in CMIP5 simulations: network connectivity from the recent past to the twenty-third century | Climate Dynamics (2014)

Climate Networks: Climate data (such as temperature or pressure) from different geographical locations can be represented as a network. In this network, nodes represent locations, and edges represent correlations or interactions between climate variables at these locations. This approach helps in identifying key regions that influence global climate patterns. Networks of climate change: connecting causes and consequences | Applied Network Science | Full Text
Teleconnections: Network analysis is used to study teleconnections, which are long-distance relationships between climate variables (like the El Niño Southern Oscillation or the North Atlantic Oscillation). By analyzing these networks, researchers can detect how changes in one part of the world affect other regions.
Extreme Event Prediction: Networks help in identifying how extreme weather events, like heat waves or storms, propagate through the system. By mapping these events in a network, it becomes easier to predict areas at risk or potential future events based on past occurrences. Climate network analysis helps pinpoint regions at higher risk of extreme weather | ScienceDaily
Feedback Loops: Network analysis is useful for identifying feedback loops in the climate system, where changes in one variable influence another, which in turn feeds back into the original variable. For example, melting ice reduces the Earth’s albedo, leading to more warming, which further accelerates ice melt.

etc. etc. etc.
If you still feel Climate modeling is a “niche” application of network analysis, you can ask the instructors for second consideration.
Kind regards

topic_title: Can we visualize outliers in scatter plot
author: iitmanupam
content:
You cannot identify outliers with precision in a scatter plot as you need the IQR or something similar for that, which a scatter plot doesn’t provide.
It will only be a visual approximation, which would be more useful as an EDA exercise.

topic_title: Can we visualize outliers in scatter plot
author: carlton
content:
Scatter plots are often used in the real world for bivariate outlier detection through the use of z scores, residuals in regression analysis, elliptic envelope (multivariate normal distribution). All these are precise mathematical tools that can be visually mapped on the scatter plot to detect outliers.
Resolution : Q444 will be given marks for both box plots as well as scatter plots being marked as the correct answer.

From the course introduction page:
image893×433 23 KB
Apart from this, I believe each question in Project 1 had an equal number of marks. For e.g., if you have 10 questions and a total of 16 marks (4 additional for peer reviews), then each correct answer should get you 1.6 marks.
Multiply the project answer marks by 5 to get your total out of 100. If you want to add peer review marks to it, multiply the marks from the answers by 4 and divide the marks from the peer reviews by 5 and add both of them to get your total marks from Project 1 out of 100.

topic_title: How was your paper and overall experience of TDS
author: eram1011
content:
Thank you for acknowledging my contribution, however small it may have been. I hope to be even more beneficial to the data science community in the future.
My journey with TDS began with great hope, inspired by its name, “Tools in Data Science,” and the practical course outline.

The first spark I felt was during the live data scraping sessions by Amit Sir, which were incredibly engaging and fun.
“Gramener” and @s.anand Sir have an indescribable aura that instills hope to achieve the depth Anand Sir has reached in the industry.
The very humble and supportive CREATIVE trio of Anand Sir, @Amit1 Sir, and @carlton Sir guided us throughout. Whether it was the ROE (which makes me wish for it in place of oppe exams) or the Mission Mars 1-mark optional projects, it was more than I could have asked for when registering for the TDS course.
One thing I feel I missed to fully experience the essence of TDS was the weekly Wednesday sessions by Dibu John Sir, as I only watched the recorded sessions on YouTube. When certain modules towards the end of the course had previous term recordings where Dibu Sir interacted with students, I felt I missed something valuable.

All the course content provided significant value, thanks to the TDS team .
Not just the official team, but the student community in TDS this term was also a delight, especially the efforts of @Arif in supporting us through the difficulties we faced.

topic_title: How was your paper and overall experience of TDS
author: eram1011
content: Regarding the end-term exam, I believe our GPT model needs further training to truly capture the essence and beauty of the subject and question design.

topic_title: How was your paper and overall experience of TDS
author: 21f3000759
content:
Thank you for tagging me.
My overall experience was kind of nice. Initially, Week 1 felt very easy but as the weeks progressed, I felt there were so many tools to learn and handle data differently. This is one of the courses where I didn’t make any handwritten notes which I usually have done for all the courses expect English (mostly done with both diplomas).
The bonus assignments quite interesting & good for practicing practical skills although I couldn’t do all due to busy schedule and health issues. I did visit discourse from time to time hoping to find more extra activity but later started helping peers & posting my doubts here.
As for ROE 1 didn’t feel it that was difficult but had I not have gotten confused with that timing issue (slowed my paced a little thinking it was an hour) I would have done 2 more questions right. It was good though.
The projects helped me put my skills to test which ROE didn’t. I used ChatGPT and it worked out so I gave that ROE marks credit to that GPT LLM.
At the very last, I was unsure how to prepare for End term but my peers helped me and will post my digital notes (that’s what I prepared a week ago) after  polishing a bit for next term students.
@s.anand sir’s guidance & teachings helped a lot in building these skills and both the TAs were there to help us @Amit1 @carlton (can’t thank enough).
@Debasmit used ChatGPT fine-tuned for TDS to generate 300+ questions which were really helpful for end term a big thanks to him.
End term was a breeze completed within 10-15 minutes with hardly 1-2 questions wrong (mistakes checked with answer key - some courses have released that)
Overall, it was a nice experience with some hiccups like issues in GAs & projects but that’s part & parcel of life (nothing is perfect). I hope I will be able to put these skills to good use in real life.
Wishing the best for everyone here…
Thanks & Regards,
Swati Jain

topic_title: How was your paper and overall experience of TDS
author: iitmanupam
content:
The course was amazing. In my eyes, it is the one course that is truly important because it shows me what life would be like in a Data Science role because more than 60% of the time in any such role is spent in data scraping, data cleaning and EDA.
For this, I need to thank Professor @s.anand and the TAs @carlton and @Amit1. Without their effort, it would not have been possible for me to roll my sleeves up and get into the thick of it, even if it was at a beginner’s level. I hope I can find some roles in the industry which allow me to explore this area a bit more in a real life project.
I also feel that given the importance and practical nature of this course, it should be converted to 4 credits with a proper structure and full time instructors to assist the Professor and students.

topic_title: How was your paper and overall experience of TDS
author: 21f3002243
content:
For me it was more than any 3 credit course being more practical than theoretical with full of experiments on data. I was aware of data analysis at high level before but this course delved me into the new realm of data analytics, drawing insights, trends by help of data visualization.
Special thanks to Professor @s.anand and TAs @Amit1, @carlton. Their extensive support and active help on discourse without which this would have been a mess. Exposing to a real world like project rather than restricting to toy example is what makes this subject.
Talking about ROE, It was hard but again LLM was a savior. It did taught one thing how to tackle a problem under pressure of time.
End term was everyone’s comfort zone I guess. Thanks to the one who made the Chat GPT TDS TA. It crafted the questions well and due to which everyone was able to give end term. Also special thanks to @carlton who conducted a mock for TDS which help to understand difficulty level of questions and gave students a confidence about end term.
Regards,
Palash H
PS. Encourage everyone those who visit this post, feel free to share your experience of TDS.

topic_title: How was your paper and overall experience of TDS
author: 22f1000022
content:
Thank you for tagging me.
I thoroughly enjoyed each and every piece of the course, right from the beginning. As a person coming from a zero programming background,  I had to endure the various pain points associated with the course (i am talking about myself) specifically in fetching and scrapping data.  I slowly started gaining confidence after watching the videos and TA session recordings multiple times.
But that confidence was only short lived as I  was completely  overrun by the ROE juggernaut. I thought ROE is a real out of the box masterclass . It prepares one to handle real world decision making situations in a better way (utilizing limited resources in a optimal manner).
I would say the course was very well designed and structured capturing all the widely used DS tools. It is also heartening to see the course contents being regularly updated to remain in sync with the rapidly changing  tools and technologies used in data science.
At the end of it, it is only postive takeaways for me from this course.  Specifically:

Exposure to various tools used in present day DS industry.
Kindling interest to delve deeper in to these tools.
Giving a birds eye view of the meaningful usage of data and kniiting interesting narratives from it.

Professor @ s.anand made the course all the more intersting and lively. Special thanks to him for sharing his rich corporate experience with the students.
My TDS experience will not be complete without  according special mention to @carlton and @Amit1 for their  commitment and handholding throughout the term.
I feel this course should find a much higher spot than a mere 3 credit course in the whole BS degree programme.
Best regards,
Rajesh Ramakrishnan

author: Kartik1
content:
This course never fails to surprise us, whether it was the impossible ROE exam, the easiest end term exam or the sarcastic posts and responses from TA’s and the professor.
I want to take a minute to appreciate and thank the entire TDS team for this amazing course and for their efforts in teaching us in a fun and challenging way. I don’t know whether i will score good or not in this course but by far this was the most enlightening course i have ever taken in this degree.
The course content was very well designed and it taught us the tools in data science in most practical way possible. Learning from @s.anand Sir felt like learning from some data science wizard, his ways made me think about data storytelling from a whole new perspective and also helped me in doing some data analytics projects for my resume.
A special thanks to @carlton , for replying to each and every query/doubt on this course from the day 1, looking at someone putting in so much efforts motivates us to do better.
Goodbye, TDS !

author: 21f3000759
content: Yes, I would also want to convey the same and also a big thank you to @s.anand sir & hearty thanks @carlton who put in every effort to help others

Thank you @s.anand sir for designing this course in such a beautiful way covering so many important aspects. author: RajatShenoi
content:
I finished TDS in about 15 minutes. It was the only exam in the AN session for me too. In the remaining time i also attempted MLF (I had that in FN session) and realised that AN version was much easier, then I completed Python and English 1 paper too (and had 10 minutes remaining).
It’s crazy when you realise that the same paper that took me 3 hours to finish when i was in foundation level (Python and English) took me just about 45 minutes now.
I dont know if the afternoon sessions exams are actually easy or if i just felt that way. But tbh i dont really know what else they could ask in the end term for TDS since this course is more about knowing the tools than the actual syntax and stuff. Either way i just hope that the project scores are not a disappointment and that they change their minds and do relative grading for the ROE.
The experience in this course was great with loads of practical learning. Thanks for that to the team.

Hello @s.anand. There was a post yesterday from @carlton regarding the end term exam (link provided below):



Syllabus and Tips for End Term TDS Tools in Data Science

Exam time: 1.5 hours

Since there are a lot of new elements introduced in the course this time and the exam pattern is changing (maybe similar to May 23 ET?), it would be really helpful if we could understand which apps/tools we should cover to manage our prep for the end term.

author: carlton
content:
I realise it sounds scary, but it will not be very deep. Just very broad. Just being familiar with the concepts (on a conceptual level) and familiar with what the tools are, which tool to use, for what purpose, basic functions of those tools (again not deep, just the most important/commonly used functions) will be all that is expected.
Additionally you will have to be familiar with the jargon of data science ( so any time some one mentions a term in the videos, like k anonymity etc) just be familiar with what those mean. Even though the questions are brand new, they will cover the same familiar areas. Data science has not changed that much, but the tools have evolved and the workflows have improved.
Hope that gives a little clarity and confidence. We will take revision sessions for the rest of the term to give you more confidence and prepare you for the end term.
Kind regards

A discrepancy form has been sent via email to all registered TDS students.
Deadline: 11 Sept, 2024
Form Submission Window Opens: 29th Aug
Please use the form to report any marks discrepancies in the GA, Projects and ROE

topic_title: Official Announcement: TDS Discrepancy Form May 2024
author: carlton
content:
Hi Hari,

We currently have left the deadline open ended until we have been given a date for final scores by the operations team.
GA6, P1, P2, GA4 scoring for individual answers will be pushed by tomorrow morning.
GA 6.2 an 6.3 solution is pair wise distance between two locations. You have to count the pairs less than the parameterised distance. The GA itself has the wrong answer key, but we do have the submissions of all students. Typically the right answer was within ±1 of the answers shown. If thats the case you will be awarded the mark, if you selected the right answer. If the correct answer was outside the range displayed you will be awarded the mark as well.
(see point 2)

Hope that gives some clarity.
Kind regards

topic_title: Solution to TDS Project "Wrong answer thing"
author: 21f3000759
content:
Hello,
I saw a lot of my friends still struggling with wrong answer thing which says -
Your submission has wrong answers. Please recheck the submission
Solution - 
Use notepad or simple text editors
Format
Q1, 678
Q2,“Answer”
Q3,7.89
Save as csv file you can name it anything.
Why without quotes thing is working yet not recommended???
When you use Excel or Google sheets - they by default add quotes for strings (See image below - it doesn’t have correct answers just shared for format) so when you add quotes - you get triple quotes into csv which generates error
image1195×585 41.6 KB
How to fix using Excel or Google sheets???
Don’t use Excel it has an inconsistent formatting as you can see Q4 there are no quotes which creates an issue
For Google sheets just write without quotes because by default it adds quotes when converted to csv. After downloading you can just use "Open in notepad option" to ensure correct formatting and submit. 
I hope this resolves the problem. In case its still unresolved please recheck your answers.
Created another post to share solution the previous two threads have way to many posts.
Thanks & Regards,
Swati Jain

author: carlton
content:
Hi Anupam,
There is nothing wrong with the script. EVEN if you answer one answer correctly, it still means you have wrong answers for the rest of them. Therefore the script correctly states that your submission has wrong answers. In other words it does not tell you which answers you got wrong.
Hope that gives clarity. (Unlike in the past where you could just submit one at a time until you get all the answers correct. You will not be able to do that with the current script).
Kind regards

author: Kartik1
content:
Inspired by @s.anand Sir’s Manhattan coffee project, i tried to create something similar like that for any indian city . I chose Domino’s and Pizza hut in Bangalore. I would really appreciate any kind of feedback on this project , the project is just in the beginning phase and i want improve it more to make it more interesting and useful.
https://pizzawarsbykartik.netlify.app/

author: carlton
content:
Hi Kartik Mittal,
Great work with the data collection, processing and visualisation. Here are some suggestions for improvements.

You should give references for where you obtained the data. This helps the reviewer to know if your sources are reliable. eg. market valued at over $145 billion (when was this and where did you get this data) What is the market value in India/Bangalore? etc.
The data you used for the population was 2011, is the data for the stores also from 2011? If you mix and match data from two different timescales, is the conclusion valid? Have you used projection or data from more recent sources that project reliably the population in the districts as it stands today?
The heat map requires a legend indicating which areas are high population vs which are low.
Show only each vendors distribution when doing the conclusions. Otherwise its difficult to see how you reached those conclusions.
Are you able to create an interactive deployment for the visualisation, so that users can explore your creation?

Its a great display of how to use all the various data tools to create a visually compelling story.
Kind regards

author: Kartik1
content: Thanks for the feedback and suggestions , i will definitely try to improve on the mentioned points.

author: 21f3001724
content:
AmodhNaik:

I would like to add that I have attempted using geodesic and geopy.distance


Bit of a dumb question & I’m 94% sure the answer is “yes obviously I checked this”, but are you sure you’re using the correct distance formula?
From everything I’ve looked up, geopy.distance.distance does not return the distance the questions are expecting. Specifically it calculates distance using a model of the earth where it is a uniform ellipse.
By contrast the Haversine formula they’ve asked for assumes the earth is a big sphere. For that, use the geopy.distance.great_circle() formula.

topic_title: G.A. 6 Q2, Q3, Pairwise distances for all businesses - is there an efficient way?
author: 21f3001724
content:
TLDR, computing the distances & storing them in the dataframe is gonna take a bit under an hour. Am I doing things in the most inefficient way humanly possible, or is it just meant to take that long?
Also,
It should not take that long. My emperical testing (in terms of time taken per row) tells me it will, but estimating things in terms of no. of operations tells me max it should take a few minutes. What’s up with that?
First
Am I being insane & doing things in the most basic & therefore most inefficient way possible.
Here’s my approach. I took eateries.csv, read it as pandas dataframe, got all the unique business_ids as a numpy array.
Created a new dist_df = pd.Dataframe(a [3623,3623] ndarray of np.inf values, index = all_biz_ids, rows = all_biz_ids)
Created a nested for loop (using iloc & some other schenaneigans to work “iteratively” w/ pandas)
for each biz_id:
          for each biz_id : (if they are not the exact same)
                          look into the eateries df to get the latitudes & longitudes, compute the distance, 
                            assign it to the corresponding cell in dist_df

My code works, its just taking a bit under a second per row (I got that by temporarily adding a print row_no into my main for loop). There are 3623 rows. It is going to take an hour.
If that was the intent & part of the point is get that things can be time consuming, that’s fine, my current plan is to run this thing while I’m eating lunch. But I’m 95% sure that was not the intent and I am just being an absolute mad man/simpleton.

Second
Second. Why is it taking this long? (my current guess is that reading from and/or writing to pandas takes WAY longer than a standard “operation” in python takes)
Here’s my rough estimate for how long this should take.
The python interpretor can handle roughly  10^7  operations per second. Alright. There’s 3623 unique businesses. Squaring that, I need to compute 1,31,26,129 distances (actually I need to compute half of that many pairs cuz of how my for loop is done but let’s just ignore that).
Let’s be really generous & say computing the distances for a pair of points requires 50 operations (I’m really trying to invent a worst possible case scenario here).
That’s still 50 \times 1,31,26,129 = 65,63,06,450  operations which divided by 10^7 \times 60 tells me this should take on the order or magnitude of a couple of minutes.
That’s still a while in absolute terms, but its a lot less than an hour.
My laptop’s specs aren’t the limitting factor either, I run adope after effects (possibly the worlds least optimized, most needlessly hungry application outside of a never ending while loop) on this thing & it handles it well; outside of the GPU (which is just integrated graphics) its a very well speced & fairly new chap.

topic_title: G.A. 6 Q2, Q3, Pairwise distances for all businesses - is there an efficient way?
author: carlton
content:
The first big optimization you would do is cut the duplicate calculations that your logic would have. You only need to compute the top half of the triangular matrix, the rest would be just duplicate calculations if you visualise the relationships between the sets of businesses as a matrix.
For loops with pandas is one the most inefficient way to deal with pandas dataframes.
For all you aspiring data scientists, if you want to level up from pottering panda to Kung fu panda, Please read on…
Efficiently iterating over rows in a Pandas DataFrame
by
Maxime Labonne
Ph.D., Staff ML Scientist @ Liquid AI • Author of “Hands-On Graph Neural Networks”
Published in
Towards Data Science
Mar 21, 2022
6 min read
1280×720 200 KB
Image by author, emojis by OpenMoji (CC BY-SA 4.0).
When I started machine learning, I followed the guidelines and created my own features by combining multiple columns in my dataset. It’s all well and good, but the way I did it was horribly inefficient. I had to wait several minutes to do the most basic operations.
My problem was simple: I didn’t know the fastest way to iterate over rows in Pandas.
I often see people online using the same techniques I used to apply. It’s not elegant but it’s ok if you don’t have much data. However, if you process more than 10k rows, it quickly becomes an obvious performance issue.
In this article, I’m gonna give you the best way to iterate over rows in a Pandas DataFrame, with no extra code required. It’s not just about performance: it’s also about understanding what’s going on under the hood to become a better data scientist.
Let’s import a dataset in Pandas. In this case, I chose the one I worked on when I started: it’s time to fix my past mistakes! 
You can run the code with the following Google Colab notebook.
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
df = pd.read_csv(‘https://raw.githubusercontent.com/mlabonne/how-to-data-science/main/data/nslkdd_test.txt’)
This dataset has 22k rows and 43 columns with a combination of categorical and numerical values. Each row describes a connection between two computers.
Let’s say we want to create a new feature: the total number of bytes in the connection. We just have to sum up two existing features: src_bytes and dst_bytes. Let’s see different methods to calculate this new feature.
 1. Iterrows
According to the official documentation, iterrows() iterates “over the rows of a Pandas DataFrame as (index, Series) pairs”. It converts each row into a Series object, which causes two problems:

It can change the type of your data (dtypes);
The conversion greatly degrades performance.

For these reasons, the ill-named iterrows() is the WORST possible method to actually iterate over rows.
%%timeit -n 10
# Iterrows
total = []
for index, row in df.iterrows():
total.append(row['src_bytes'] + row['dst_bytes'])


10 loops, best of 5: 1.07 s per loop

Now let’s see slightly better techniques…
 2. For loop with .loc or .iloc (3× faster)
This is what I used to do when I started: a basic for loop to select rows by index (with .loc or .iloc).
Why is it bad? Because DataFrames are not designed for this purpose. As with the previous method, rows are converted into Pandas Series objects, which degrades performance.
Interestingly enough,.iloc is faster than .loc. It makes sense since Python doesn’t have to check user-defined labels and directly look at where the row is stored in memory.
%%timeit -n 10
# For loop with .loc
total = []
for index in range(len(df)):
total.append(df['src_bytes'].loc[index] + df['dst_bytes'].loc[index])


10 loops, best of 5: 600 ms per loop

%%timeit -n 10
# For loop with .iloc
total = []
for index in range(len(df)):
total.append(df['src_bytes'].iloc[index] + df['dst_bytes'].iloc[index])


10 loops, best of 5: 377 ms per loop

Even this basic for loop with .iloc is 3 times faster than the first method!
 3. Apply (4× faster)
The apply() method is another popular choice to iterate over rows. It creates code that is easy to understand but at a cost: performance is nearly as bad as the previous for loop.
This is why I would strongly advise you to avoid this function for this specific purpose (it’s fine for other applications).
Note that I convert the DataFrame into a list using the to_list() method to obtain identical results.
%%timeit -n 10
# Apply
df.apply(lambda row: row['src_bytes'] + row['dst_bytes'], axis=1).to_list()


10 loops, best of 5: 282 ms per loop

The apply() method is a for loop in disguise, which is why the performance doesn’t improve that much: it’s only 4 times faster than the first technique.
 4. Itertuples (10× faster)
If you know about iterrows(), you probably know about itertuples(). According to the official documentation, it iterates “over the rows of a DataFrame as namedtuples of the values”. In practice, it means that rows are converted into tuples, which are much lighter objects than Pandas Series.
This is why itertuples() is a better version of iterrows(). This time, we need to access the values with an attribute (or an index). If you want to access them with a string (e.g., if there’s a space in the string), you can use the getattr() function instead.
%%timeit -n 10
# Itertuples
total = []
for row in df.itertuples():
total.append(row.src_bytes + row.dst_bytes)


10 loops, best of 5: 99.3 ms per loop

This is starting to look better: it is now 10 times faster than iterrows() .
 5. List comprehensions (200× faster)
List comprehensions are a fancy way to iterate over a list as a one-liner.
For instance, [print(i) for i in range(10)] prints numbers from 0 to 9 without any explicit for loop. I say “explicit” because Python actually processes it as a for loop if we look at the bytecode.
So why is it faster? Quite simply because we don’t call the .append() method in this version.
%%timeit -n 100
# List comprehension
[src + dst for src, dst in zip(df['src_bytes'], df['dst_bytes'])]


100 loops, best of 5: 5.54 ms per loop

Indeed, this technique is 200 times faster than the first one! But we can still do better.
 6. Pandas vectorization (1500× faster)
Until now, all the techniques used simply add up single values. Instead of adding single values, why not group them into vectors to sum them up? The difference between adding two numbers or two vectors is not significant for a CPU, which should speed things up.
On top of that, Pandas can process Series objects in parallel, using every CPU core available!
The syntax is also the simplest imaginable: this solution is extremely intuitive. Under the hood, Pandas takes care of vectorizing our data with an optimized C code using contiguous memory blocks.
%%timeit -n 1000
# Vectorization
(df['src_bytes'] + df['dst_bytes']).to_list()


1000 loops, best of 5: 734 µs per loop

This code is 1500 times faster than iterrows() and it is even simpler to write.
 7. NumPy vectorization (1900× faster)
NumPy is designed to handle scientific computing. It has less overhead than Pandas methods since rows and dataframes all become np.array. It relies on the same optimizations as Pandas vectorization.
There are two ways of converting a Series into a np.array: using .values or .to_numpy(). The former has been deprecated for years, which is why we’re gonna use .to_numpy() in this example.
%%timeit -n 1000
# Numpy vectorization
(df['src_bytes'].to_numpy() + df['dst_bytes'].to_numpy()).tolist()


1000 loops, best of 5: 575 µs per loop

We found our winner with a technique that is 1900 times faster than our first competitor! Let’s wrap things up.
 Conclusion
1400×720 136 KB
The number of rows in the dataset can greatly impact the performance of certain techniques (image by author).
Don’t be like me: if you need to iterate over rows in a DataFrame, vectorization is the way to go! You can find the code to reproduce the experiments at this address. Vectorization is not harder to read, it doesn’t take longer to write, and the performance gain is incredible.
It’s not just about performance: understanding how each method works under the hood helped me to write better code. Performance gains are always based on the same techniques: transforming data into vectors and matrices to take advantage of parallel processing. Alas, this is often at the expense of readability. But it doesn’t have to be.
Iterating over rows is just an example but it shows that, sometimes, you can have the cake and eat it. 

Kind regards,
From your friendly TDS TA
PS.

“There is no cake”
by the test subject Doug Rattman in the Aperture Science Computer-Aided Enrichment Center  before his untimely demise caused by the artificially superintelligent computer GlaDOS.
